verses.text: Now I remind you, brothers, of the gospel I proclaimed to you, which you received, in which you stand,
verses.comment: Paul starts by recalling the foundational gospel message, emphasizing the continuity of tradition and the importance of holding fast to the apostolic teaching.

verses.text: by which you are being saved, if you hold firmly to the word I preached to you—unless you believed in vain.
verses.comment: Salvation comes through perseverance in the faith and fidelity to the original apostolic proclamation, highlighting the importance of tradition and its transmission.

verses.text: For I delivered to you as of first importance what I also received: that Christ died for our sins in accordance with the Scriptures,
verses.comment: Paul references a tradition he received, reflecting a pattern of transmission of teachings. The phrase 'in accordance with the Scriptures' shows prophecy fulfillment.

verses.text: that he was buried, that he was raised on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures,
verses.comment: Christ's burial and resurrection fulfill Old Testament prophecies; the third day reference echoes Jonah and Davidic prophecy, reinforcing messianic identity.

verses.text: and that he appeared to Cephas, then to the twelve.
verses.comment: The order of appearances underscores the primacy of certain apostles, beginning with Cephas (Peter) as the lead witness among the apostles.

verses.text: Then he appeared to more than five hundred brothers at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have fallen asleep.
verses.comment: The resurrection appearances were witnessed by a large group, providing strong testimony to the event’s reality. 'Fallen asleep' is a euphemism for death, anticipating the theme of resurrection.

verses.text: Then he appeared to James, then to all the apostles.
verses.comment: James, the Lord’s brother, is singled out among the apostolic witnesses, showing the leadership structure already present in the early Church.

verses.text: Last of all, as to one untimely born, he appeared also to me.
verses.comment: Paul’s personal encounter with the risen Christ on the road to Damascus affirms apostolic authority rooted in direct revelation.

verses.text: For I am the least of the apostles, unworthy to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the Church of God.
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges his past as a persecutor, stressing humility and the transforming power of divine grace.

verses.text: But by the grace of God I am what I am, and his grace toward me was not in vain. On the contrary, I worked harder than any of them—yet not I, but the grace of God that is with me.
verses.comment: Paul's work is attributed to God's grace within him, highlighting cooperative synergy between divine grace and human effort.

verses.text: Whether then it was I or they, so we preach and so you believed.
verses.comment: Unity of apostolic witness; the gospel’s substance does not depend on the messenger.

verses.text: Now if Christ is proclaimed as raised from the dead, how can some of you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?
verses.comment: Paul challenges doubts about bodily resurrection, which was contested by some philosophical groups.

verses.text: But if there is no resurrection of the dead, then not even Christ has been raised.
verses.comment: The resurrection of believers is inseparably linked to Christ’s own resurrection.

verses.text: And if Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is empty, and your faith is also empty.
verses.comment: The Christ event is the basis of Christian faith, without which all proclamation and belief is futile.

verses.text: Moreover, we are found to be false witnesses about God, because we testified about God that he raised Christ—whom he did not raise if in fact the dead are not raised.
verses.comment: To deny the resurrection is to undermine apostolic witness and the truthfulness of God’s revelation.

verses.text: For if the dead are not raised, then not even Christ has been raised.
verses.comment: Repetition stresses the interconnectivity between Christ’s rising and ours.

verses.text: And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile and you are still in your sins.
verses.comment: Resurrection is the assurance of forgiveness and victory over sin, foundational to Christian hope.

verses.text: Then those who have fallen asleep in Christ have perished.
verses.comment: Without resurrection, death remains unconquered and those departed in Christ have no hope beyond the grave.

verses.text: If in Christ we have hope in this life only, we are of all people most to be pitied.
verses.comment: The implication is that Christian faith and suffering only make sense in light of eternal life.

verses.text: But in fact Christ has been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep.
verses.comment: ‘Firstfruits’ echoes Old Testament sacrificial offerings and anticipates the universal resurrection of believers.

verses.text: For as by a man came death, by a man has come also the resurrection of the dead.
verses.comment: Adam’s sin brought death; Christ’s obedience restores life. This shows typology, connecting Adam and Christ.

verses.text: For as in Adam all die, so also in Christ all will be made alive.
verses.comment: Universal scope: death and resurrection affect humanity as a whole, the basis for hope of bodily resurrection for all in Christ.

verses.text: But each in his own order: Christ the firstfruits, then at his coming those who belong to Christ.
verses.comment: Paul introduces a sequence: Christ first, then those united with Him at His return. This implies an organized structure to the resurrection.

verses.text: Then comes the end, when he delivers the kingdom to God the Father after destroying every rule and every authority and power.
verses.comment: Christ’s reign as King culminates in a final subjection of all hostile powers. A strong affirmation of His royal messianic role.

verses.text: For he must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.
verses.comment: Citing Psalm 110, Paul identifies Christ’s reign as a fulfillment of messianic prophecy, showing both literal and spiritual dominion.

verses.text: The last enemy to be destroyed is death.
verses.comment: Ultimate victory over death affirms bodily resurrection as central to Christian doctrine.

verses.text: For, 'God has put all things in subjection under his feet.' But when it says, 'all things are put in subjection,' it is plain that he is excepted who put all things in subjection under him.
verses.comment: Psalm 8 is referenced, showing Jesus’ messianic kingship and distinguishing the Father and the Son.

verses.text: When all things are subjected to him, then the Son himself will also be subjected to him who put all things under him, so that God may be all in all.
verses.comment: The Son’s subjection signals perfect unity and divine harmony; shows both distinction and unity within the Godhead.

verses.text: Otherwise, what do people mean by being baptized on behalf of the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why are people baptized on their behalf?
verses.comment: The obscure reference to baptism for the dead suggests belief in the effects of corporeal actions, showing early Christians' practice of prayer and intercession.

verses.text: And why are we in danger every hour?
verses.comment: Paul underscores the dangers faced in ministry, showing that enduring such peril is only rational if resurrection is real.

verses.text: I protest, brothers, by my pride in you, which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die every day!
verses.comment: Paul’s daily trials point to living out the death and resurrection of Christ continually, signifying spiritual transformation.

verses.text: If I fought with wild beasts at Ephesus for human motives, what does it profit me? If the dead are not raised, 'Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes Isaiah, contrasting existential nihilism with the hope of resurrection.

verses.text: Do not be deceived: 'Bad company ruins good morals.'
verses.comment: Paul cites popular wisdom literature, emphasizing the ethical implications of doctrinal error for communal holiness.

verses.text: Wake up from your drunkenness, as is right, and do not sin. For some have no knowledge of God. I say this to your shame.
verses.comment: Paul calls for moral awakening, correlating ignorance of God with a lack of holiness.

verses.text: But someone will ask, 'How are the dead raised? With what kind of body do they come?'
verses.comment: Paul addresses skepticism regarding physical resurrection, setting up a theological explanation of transformation.

verses.text: You foolish person! What you sow does not come to life unless it dies.
verses.comment: Paul uses agricultural imagery, paralleling Jesus’ teaching about the seed dying to bear much fruit.

verses.text: And what you sow is not the body that is to be, but a bare seed, perhaps of wheat or of some other kind.
verses.comment: Transformation from seed to plant illustrates the resurrection body being distinctly superior and glorified compared to the physical body.

verses.text: But God gives it a body as He has chosen, and to each kind of seed its own body.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty determines the nature of resurrection, reinforcing His creative power.

verses.text: Not all flesh is the same, but there is one kind for humans, another for animals, another for birds, and another for fish.
verses.comment: Diversity in creation points to varying forms in resurrection; the physical differences in creation anticipate the glorified body.

verses.text: There are heavenly bodies and earthly bodies, but the glory of the heavenly is of one kind, and the glory of the earthly is of another.
verses.comment: Paul illustrates qualitative difference between resurrection body and earthly body, with glory increasing in the spiritual realm.

verses.text: There is one glory of the sun, another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for star differs from star in glory.
verses.comment: Hierarchy of glories in the created order parallels the resurrection differences among believers.

verses.text: So also is the resurrection of the dead. What is sown is perishable; what is raised is imperishable.
verses.comment: Corruptible nature of earthly existence is transformed to incorruptibility in resurrection.

verses.text: It is sown in dishonor; it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness; it is raised in power.
verses.comment: Contrast between present mortality and future glorification; the spiritual body is marked by divine power.

verses.text: It is sown a natural body; it is raised a spiritual body. If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual body.
verses.comment: Paul affirms bodily resurrection, countering gnostic and docetic errors by asserting both continuity and transformation.

verses.text: So it is written, 'The first man Adam became a living being'; the last Adam became a life-giving Spirit.
verses.comment: Adam’s natural life contrasts with Christ’s life-giving spiritual power. Christ as the New Adam fulfills the typology of redemption.

verses.text: But it is not the spiritual that is first, but the natural, and then the spiritual.
verses.comment: Affirms the progression from physical birth to spiritual transformation—suggesting the sacramental journey towards perfection.

verses.text: The first man was from the earth, a man of dust; the second man is from heaven.
verses.comment: Paul highlights Christ’s heavenly origin, echoing high Christology by linking Him directly to divinity.

verses.text: As was the man of dust, so also are those who are of the dust; and as is the man of heaven, so also are those who are of heaven.
verses.comment: Believers are conformed to Christ’s heavenly image, not merely restored to Adam’s pre-fall state but elevated beyond.

verses.text: And just as we have borne the image of the man of dust, we shall also bear the image of the man of heaven.
verses.comment: Promise of transformation, showing both literal future resurrection and spiritual renewal in Christ.

verses.text: Now I declare this, brothers: flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, nor does the perishable inherit the imperishable.
verses.comment: Entrance into the kingdom requires transformation, implying a sacramental process that prepares believers for glorification.

verses.text: Listen, I tell you a mystery: we will not all sleep, but we will all be changed,
verses.comment: Paul reveals an apocalyptic mystery, emphasizing sudden transformation of all believers—collective, not just individual, salvation.

verses.text: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we shall be changed.
verses.comment: Eschatological imagery underlines both bodily resurrection and enduring transformation for eternal life.

verses.text: For this perishable must put on the imperishable, and this mortal must put on immortality.
verses.comment: Paul describes the change from mortal to immortal existence, the fulfillment of the divine promise for believers.

verses.text: When the perishable has put on the imperishable, and the mortal has put on immortality, then the saying that is written will be fulfilled: 'Death is swallowed up in victory.'
verses.comment: Direct fulfillment of prophetic promises, showing Christ’s triumph over death fulfills Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'O death, where is your victory? O death, where is your sting?'
verses.comment: Paul poetically taunts defeated death, echoing Hosea and prophetic victory through Christ.

verses.text: The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
verses.comment: Death comes through sin, whose power is magnified by the law—showing need for grace as transformative and liberating.

verses.text: But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The victory through Christ is both a present reality and future hope, received by grace and mediated through union with Christ.

verses.text: Therefore, my beloved brothers, be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that your labor in the Lord is not in vain.
verses.comment: Paul ends by exhorting perseverance. The promise of resurrection grounds continual good works, affirmed and rewarded in eternity, suggesting a theology of merit and hope.
